EDITORIAL COMMENT
NOBLE IN PURPOSE

FROM GILMAN TOWR
By SumNER L. SlocicroN -----,
The street which runs by the campus—familiarly known as Charles
Street—holds more interest for me
than any other in the city. I think
it ,might easily and- deservedly be
called the. most important of all.
Surely no other runs so nonchalantly past poverty and riches, and from
waterfront to open country.. Along
its path of approximately ,fifteen
miles lie representatives and vestiges
of almost every type of life—along
its patjt from the harbor to the
Joppa Road. Strangely enough it is
cut MT abruptly at both ends—a.few
feet too far at the southern extremity means a plunge into the head
waters of the harbor; a few feet too
far at the 'opposite end means a
plunge down a very steep hillside. A
day's walk along its entire length
would be, to my mind, more of an
introduction to--would give a deeper insight into—the great drama of
life than any other possible one-day
activity. And I should suggest, also,
that the southern extremity makes
the best starting point, for it leaves
you later in the solitudes of nature,
where the previous sights may best
be thought oyer.
Thus the typical waterfront scenes
are encountered first; then the numerous pseudo-suburban homes of
the laborers, surrounded by railroad
yards and factorieS; next through a
second-rate (as some people call it)
shopping district; past warehouses
and a few offices; past a market
with its varied produce; still farther
on comes Baltimore Street, where
The business district centers. From
here on Charles Street begins to
savor of wealth, with its stores, exclusive shop*, and tearooms—it -is
approaching sophistication. It runs
past old and charming city 'residences, hotels, libraries and music
halls, town clubs, -and then again
runs through a series of shops and
offices. Still farther on are city residences, educational institutions, and
apartment houses. Then Charles
Street becomes lined with fine suburban homes, beautiful gardens, and
finally ends up amidst country estates.
There are men on this street from
all types. Beggars, millionaires,
fools, sages—and the common people. As I think of Charles Street
with its all--inclusive view of life, I
wish that‘it could talk. I know that
all these:different men are seeking
happiness in their 1;rarious environments,/ but I cannot tell which—unless it is the fool—comes closest to
finding,it.

You may say that it is impossible
for an American to understand a
Frenchman anyhow, and that all
Frenchmen are therefore a bit unbalanced, and somebody will always
be broadminded enough to disagree.
But it is difficult to follow the latest
reasoning of the French Tennis
Association.
The French government has recently levied a 22 2 per cent tax on
the gross receipts of tennis matches,
looking forward to collecting a very
considerable sum at the covered
court championships. The French
Tennis Association was very much
annoyed at this, and its leaders put
their heads together with the following result:
The championships must be held.

EDITORIAL COMMENT
NOBLE IN PURPOSE

FROM GILMAN TOWR
By SumNER L. SlocicroN -----,
The street which runs by the campus—familiarly known as Charles
Street—holds more interest for me
than any other in the city. I think
it ,might easily and- deservedly be
called the. most important of all.
Surely no other runs so nonchalantly past poverty and riches, and from
waterfront to open country.. Along
its path of approximately ,fifteen
miles lie representatives and vestiges
of almost every type of life—along
its patjt from the harbor to the
Joppa Road. Strangely enough it is
cut MT abruptly at both ends—a.few
feet too far at the southern extremity means a plunge into the head
waters of the harbor; a few feet too
far at the 'opposite end means a
plunge down a very steep hillside. A
day's walk along its entire length
would be, to my mind, more of an
introduction to--would give a deeper insight into—the great drama of
life than any other possible one-day
activity. And I should suggest, also,
that the southern extremity makes
the best starting point, for it leaves
you later in the solitudes of nature,
where the previous sights may best
be thought oyer.
Thus the typical waterfront scenes
are encountered first; then the numerous pseudo-suburban homes of
the laborers, surrounded by railroad
yards and factorieS; next through a
second-rate (as some people call it)
shopping district; past warehouses
and a few offices; past a market
with its varied produce; still farther
on comes Baltimore Street, where
The business district centers. From
here on Charles Street begins to
savor of wealth, with its stores, exclusive shop*, and tearooms—it -is
approaching sophistication. It runs
past old and charming city 'residences, hotels, libraries and music
halls, town clubs, -and then again
runs through a series of shops and
offices. Still farther on are city residences, educational institutions, and
apartment houses. Then Charles
Street becomes lined with fine suburban homes, beautiful gardens, and
finally ends up amidst country estates.
There are men on this street from
all types. Beggars, millionaires,
fools, sages—and the common people. As I think of Charles Street
with its all--inclusive view of life, I
wish that‘it could talk. I know that
all these:different men are seeking
happiness in their 1;rarious environments,/ but I cannot tell which—unless it is the fool—comes closest to
finding,it.

sense of loyalty to this University
prohibits any, comment on the Blue
Jays' visit to Columbia's ball park
tomorrow, except to wish the local
team a pleasant journey.
You may say that it is impossible
for an American to understand a
Frenchman anyhow, and that all
Frenchmen are therefore a bit unbalanced, and somebody will always
be broadminded enough to disagree.
But it is difficult to follow the latest
reasoning of the French Tennis
Association.
The French government has recently levied a 22 2 per cent tax on
the gross receipts of tennis matches,
looking forward to collecting a very
considerable sum at the covered
court championships. The French
Tennis Association was very much
annoyed at this, and its leaders put
their heads together with the following result:
The championships must be held.
